confusion_pairs.title: Worm vs Virus

a.definition: Self-spreading malware that propagates automatically without user action (e.g., exploiting services, file shares, vulnerable devices).

b.definition: Malware that replicates after being activated; commonly needs a user action or infection mechanism (e.g., running a file, opening a macro, inserting media).

bullets: Worm: propagation is the headline feature; Virus: replication after activation is the feature.
Worms can spread network-wide very quickly with no clicks; viruses often need a trigger/event.
Worm outbreaks = “it spread by itself”; virus incidents = “someone executed/opened something (or the system auto-activated it).”

confusion_pairs.title: Trojan vs Worm

a.definition: Malware disguised as legitimate software; typically relies on user execution/installation.

b.definition: Self-spreading malware that propagates without user interaction.

bullets: Trojan: social engineering + disguise; Worm: automated spread.
Trojan installs because you ran it; Worm spreads because something was exposed/vulnerable.
Trojan is a delivery method; payload can be RAT/spyware/ransomware.

confusion_pairs.title: Spyware vs Keylogger

a.definition: Malware primarily intended to gather information (browsing, files, system details), possibly using many delivery methods.

b.definition: Malware or device that captures keystrokes/inputs to steal credentials and sensitive data.

bullets: Keylogger is often a *subset/tool* of spyware, but spyware is broader than keystrokes.
Keylogger gives “passwords typed”; spyware can give “everything about the user/system.”
Mitigation focus: MFA helps against keylogging credential theft; anti-spyware/EDR helps against both.

confusion_pairs.title: Rootkit vs Trojan

a.definition: Backdoor-focused malware designed to hide and persist (e.g., hooking, boot/MBR infection); makes the local system untrustworthy.

b.definition: Disguised program that gets you to install/run it; may *deliver* other malware (including rootkits).

bullets: Trojan is how you get infected; Rootkit is what makes infection hard to detect/remove.
Rootkits emphasize stealth + privileged persistence; Trojans emphasize deception at install-time.
Remediation: rootkits often justify rebuild/restore; Trojans may be cleaned if fully detected.

confusion_pairs.title: Fileless malware vs Traditional on-disk malware

a.definition: Runs primarily in memory, often leveraging scripts (e.g., PowerShell) and persistence tricks like Registry entries; may leave minimal disk artifacts.

b.definition: Stores its primary executable(s) on disk and is detected via file signatures/hashes more directly.

bullets: Fileless: behavior/EDR detection matters; On-disk: signature/hash detection is often stronger.
Fileless often exploits browsers/plugins or scripts; traditional malware often drops binaries.
Fileless persistence can be Registry keys/scheduled tasks; traditional persistence is often startup files/services.

malware.ransomware.rule: If the system is locked/encrypted *and* a payment demand appears, assume ransomware; the best recovery story is clean restore from offline/immutable backups.
malware.ransomware.micro_example: Files turn into *.locked and a note says “Pay 0.5 BTC for the key.” Restore from last known-good backup + patch the entry path.

malware.trojan.rule: If it looks legit and needs the user to run/install it, think Trojan (often a delivery wrapper for something worse).
malware.trojan.micro_example: “Invoice.pdf.exe” is opened, a fake viewer flashes, and a hidden service appears afterward.

malware.worm.rule: If it spreads without clicks, it’s probably a worm—patch/exploit containment and segmentation matter more than user training in that moment.
malware.worm.micro_example: A vulnerable service is exploited and suddenly 200 hosts are infected within minutes.

malware.spyware.rule: Spyware is defined by intent: information gathering. Delivery can look like a Trojan, worm, or ‘legit’ browser add-on.
malware.spyware.micro_example: A browser extension silently records browsing and uploads screenshots to a remote server.

malware.bloatware.rule: Bloatware isn’t always malicious, but it increases attack surface (extra code, calls home, vulnerabilities). Treat it like risk you can remove.
malware.bloatware.micro_example: A preinstalled OEM updater runs as admin and later gets exploited via a known CVE.

malware.virus.rule: Virus = trigger + payload + replication after activation; usually needs an infection mechanism (macro, attachment, media).
malware.virus.micro_example: A macro document runs when opened and drops code that infects other documents.

malware.fileless.rule: No file on disk doesn’t mean no malware: look for unusual scripting (PowerShell), memory injection, and persistence via Registry/scheduled tasks.
malware.fileless.micro_example: EDR flags PowerShell downloading code; a Registry run key appears; disk scan finds nothing.

malware.keylogger.rule: Keylogger risk = credential theft; MFA reduces impact, and physical inspections matter for hardware keyloggers.
malware.keylogger.micro_example: User reports account takeover after typing passwords on a shared PC; MFA blocks the attacker’s login.

malware.logicbomb.rule: Logic bombs live inside legitimate code and wait for a condition (date, user, event). Detection is mostly code review/integrity controls.
malware.logicbomb.micro_example: On ‘termination_date’, a hidden function deletes customer records.

malware.rootkit.rule: If you can’t trust the host to tell the truth, treat it like a rootkit: validate from trusted media and strongly consider rebuild/restore.
malware.rootkit.micro_example: Local AV says “clean,” but trusted boot media finds hidden drivers and altered boot components.
